sentences.sentence: She was led by a servant into the breakfast-room, where she received another distressing( 令人苦恼的 ) report of her sister’s condition.
Miss Bennet had slept poorly, and though awake, was very feverish, and not well enough to leave her room.
Elizabeth spent most of the day and night in her sister’s room, and the next morning found her sister’s condition had improved significantly( 显著地 ).
The next day passed much better than the day before had done, and in the evening Elizabeth joined the others in the drawing-room.
Mr. Darcy was writing, and Miss Bingley, seated near him, was watching as he wrote his letter.
When he had finished his letter, Mr. Darcy asked Miss Bingley and Elizabeth to play some music.
Miss Bingley moved with some speed to the piano, and after politely requesting that Elizabeth would play first, she seated herself.
While Miss Bingley was playing, Elizabeth could not help observing how frequently Mr. Darcy’s eyes were fixed on herself.
She hardly imagined that she could be an object of admiration to so great a man.
She could only guess that he at last began to notice her because he found her more intolerable( 无法忍受的 ) than any other person present.
This thought did not upset her, because she liked him too little to care.
After playing some slow songs, Miss Bingley played a livelier tune( 曲子 ), and soon afterward( 之后 ) Mr. Darcy came over to Elizabeth and said to her:
“Miss Bennet, will you take this opportunity to dance?”
She smiled, but made no answer.
He repeated the question, with some surprise at her silence.
“Oh!” she said, “I heard you before, but I could not immediately decide what to say in reply.
You wanted me, I know, to say ‘Yes,’ that you might then take pleasure in despising( 看不起 ) my taste in music.
I have, therefore, made up my mind to tell you, that I do not want to dance at all—and now despise( 看不起 ) me if you dare.”
“Indeed I do not dare.”
Elizabeth, having rather expected to offend( 冒犯 ) him, was amazed( 惊讶的 ) at his politeness.
Darcy, for his part, had never been as charmed( 着迷 ) by any woman as he was by her.
He really believed that were it not for the inferiority( 社会地位低 ) of her social connections, he would be in some danger of falling deeply in love.
After dinner that evening, Elizabeth helped her sister down the stairs( 楼梯 ) and into the drawing-room, where Jane was welcomed by Caroline Bingley with many expressions of pleasure.
But when the gentlemen joined the ladies, Jane was no longer the center of attention.
Miss Bingley’s eyes were instantly turned toward Darcy, and she had something to say before he had approached many steps.
Made desperate( 急切的 ) by the strength of her feelings for Mr. Darcy, she turned to Elizabeth and said:
“Miss Eliza Bennet, please take a walk with me around the room.
It is very refreshing( 提神的 ) after sitting for so long.”
Elizabeth was surprised, but agreed to it immediately.
Miss Bingley succeeded in achieving the real purpose of her politeness, because Mr. Darcy looked up.
He was directly invited to join them, but he declined( 拒绝 ).
He commented that he could imagine only two motives( 动机 ) for their choosing to walk up and down the room together, and that he did not wish to interfere( 干涉 ) with either.
Miss Bingley was desperate( 急切的 ) to know what his two motives( 动机 ) could be and kept asking.
“I have no objection to explaining them,” Mr. Darcy said.
“You choose this method of passing the evening either because you have secrets to discuss, or because you are aware that your figures appear most attractive when walking.
If it is the first motive( 动机 ), I would be completely in your way.
If the second, I can admire you much better as I sit by the fire.”
“Shocking!” Miss Bingley cried.
“I never heard anything so rude.
How shall we punish him for such a speech?”
“Nothing could be easier, if that is your desire,” Elizabeth said.
“Tease( 取笑 ) him—laugh at( 嘲笑 ) him. Intimate( 亲密的 ) as you are, you must know how it can be done.”
“But how can we tease( 取笑 ) such calmness of manner and presence of mind?
Such a man hardly deserves to be laughed at( 嘲笑 ).”
“Mr. Darcy is not to be laughed at( 嘲笑 )!” Elizabeth cried.
“That is very uncommon, and I hope it remains uncommon, because I dearly love to laugh.”
“Miss Bingley,” Darcy said,
“has given me more credit than I deserve.
The wisest and the best of men may be made to look ridiculous( 可笑的 ) by a person whose first aim in life is a joke.”
“Certainly,” Elizabeth replied,
“there are such people, but I hope I am not one of them.
I hope I never ridicule( 嘲笑 ) what is wise and good.
Foolishness and stupidity, I laugh at whenever I can.
But these, I suppose, are precisely what you are without.”
“Perhaps that is not possible for anyone.
But I have worked hard to avoid those weaknesses which could be laughed at.”
“Such as vanity( 自负 ) and pride.”
“Yes, vanity( 自负 ) is a weakness indeed.
But pride—where there is a real superiority of intelligence, pride will always be kept well under control.”
Elizabeth turned away to hide a smile.
“Your examination of Mr. Darcy is over, I presume( 认为 ),” Miss Bingley said,
“and tell me, what is the result?”
“I am perfectly convinced( 确信的 ) that Mr. Darcy has no faults.
He openly admits it himself.”
“No,” Darcy said, “I have made no such claim.
I have enough faults, but they are not, I hope, failures of judgment.
My temper I dare not mention.
I cannot forgive others as soon as I should.
My temper would perhaps be called resentful( 怨恨的 ).
My good opinion, once lost, is lost forever.”
“That is a fault indeed!” Elizabeth cried.
“Unforgiving resentment( 怨恨 ) is a flaw( 缺点 ) in character.
But you have chosen your fault well.
I really cannot laugh at it.
You are safe from me.”
“There is, I believe, in everyone a tendency to some particular evil( 邪恶 )—a natural defect( 缺点 ), which not even the best education can overcome.”
“And your defect( 缺点 ) is to hate everybody.”
“And yours,” he replied with a smile, “is to willfully( 蓄意地 ) misunderstand them.”
“Do let us have a little music,” Miss Bingley cried, tired of a conversation in which she had nothing to say.
“Would anybody mind my opening the piano?”
Nobody made any objection, and the piano was opened.
Darcy, after a few moments’ thought, was not sorry that the conversation had ended.
He began to feel the danger of paying Elizabeth too much attention.
